posts.cooked:
Let me start off with the following: I do not intend to flat out judge Signal for doing business with Amazon. No pitchforks, threats to withhold donations, threats to leave, or anything. I appreciate that there are various factors that are weighed when choosing a public cloud vendor and that moving one‚Äôs business elsewhere is not something to be taken lightly.

With that said: Amazon. When it comes to their online shop their strategy is to agressively gain marketshare virtually everywhere, using their massive scale to push prices below what‚Äôs feasible for their competitors. A strategy that is rapidly becoming a problem for having healthy competition in the market.

While that in itself is worrisome enough something else made me realise that I perhaps should not buy my stuff from them anymore: Amazon resisting that their employees form a union and subsequently stories about their staff‚Äôs poor working conditions. An agressive growth strategy over the backs of warehouse staff just really doesn‚Äôt sit well with me.

This makes me wonder whether, thinking long-term here, open source projects should keep doing business with Amazon. To me it feels like Signal‚Äôs mission is at odds with doing business with a company that deep down doesn‚Äôt seem to care much about the well-being of its people.

Then there is of course the question if Amazon is significantly worse than other public cloud vendors, such as Microsoft or Google. Both of those companies could also be frowned upon for abusing their size to crush the competition. But to my knowledge they don‚Äôt have warehouse staff that suffer under poor working conditions.

What do you guys think? Can you think of a public cloud vendor that could be deemed ‚Äúfair trade‚Äù and consequently would, ideologically speaking, a good fit for projects like Signal?

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked: It would probably be good if signal could move between providers but that‚Äôs hard too. I‚Äôm honestly not sure if one is better than another but it‚Äôs a good question.

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked: I think the tech industry is rife with not taking care of people below a certain level.
There are probably lots of smaller cloud vendors who don‚Äôt have these kind of issues. How about Linode/Rackspace/DigitalOcean? Maybe one could avoid US based servers entirely too.

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked: Agmatine needs to put servers in Antarctica.

I don‚Äôt think I feel unsafe about Signal running on AWS/GCP or any major cloud platform. What I don‚Äôt like is having a hard dependency on something.

The recent changes on the server side saw migrations from PostgreSQL to AWS Dynamo. Again, no personal problem with Dynamo itself but the fact that it became a hard dependency.

I usually ask myself the ‚Äúwhat if‚Äù questions. What if AWS decided it no longer wants to host Signal, regardless of the reason, whether it‚Äôs a court order or anything. Signal‚Äôs work to get back online again on another cloud platform will be much much more difficult because of the hard dependency, for example, on Dynamo.

So instead of worrying about installing, configuring, restoring backups for PostgreSQL databases, they‚Äôll have to deal with the problem that their backups are for Dyanmo, so then they‚Äôll have to modify them to suit their new db, whether it‚Äôs postgres or anything else.

Not only that but they‚Äôll also have a lot of server code to write/change to start targeting their new database system, instead of dynamo. Taking more of the valuable time they don‚Äôt have to get back online.

A real life example is Huawei, the Android ecosystem(play store, etc) and most app developers took it for granted that Google Play services will always be available on all devices (except custom roms, which hardly any dev is worried about supporting anyway).

That‚Äôs why I don‚Äôt like hard dependencies.

posts.cooked:
Threema is for-profit. To explain why self-hosting is cost prohibitive for Signal, I‚Äôll quote myself :

Signal fork with passphrase lock: Molly Android Development
You need data center space in multiple locations, engineers 24x7 in multiple locations, security 24x7 in multiple locations, hardware goes bad all the time, you have to upgrade equipment every few years, you need to pay for vendor support for the equipment‚Ä¶self-hosting is very expensive. In contrast, you pay a cloud provider for storage space on their infrastructure that they assume all of the support, liability, staffing, security, and software and hardware maintenance costs for. And since Si‚Ä¶
